thread.title: One dead after head-on crash near Queenstown | Stuff.co.nz
thread.title_full: One dead after head-on crash near Queenstown | Stuff.co.nz

author: Dasha Kuprienko And Debbie Jamieson
title: One dead after head-on crash near Queenstown | Stuff.co.nz
text:
A huge fire is burning on a hillside near Christchurch ... more soon One dead after head-on crash near Queenstown DASHA KUPRIENKO AND DEBBIE JAMIESON Last updated 18:09, February 13 2017 Dasha Kuprienko 
An Otago Rescue Helicopter Trust helicopter landing at the scene of a serious car crash near Gibbston, on the outskirts of Queenstown. 
One person has died after a serious head-on car crash near Queenstown. 
Emergency services were called to the Gibbston Highway near the Crown Range about 2.30pm. 
Two people were trapped in a car, and another was thrown from another after the two-car smash near the Crown Range turn-off between Queenstown and Cromwell. Dasha Kuprienko 
People are trapped after a two car crash near Gibbston, Queenstown. 
A witness to the crash said one of the vehicles crossed the centre line. 
Mike Grant, of Invercargill, was travelling toward Queenstown and said he got "a hell of a fright" when the crash happened in heavy rain. 
"I don't know if [the car travelling toward Cromwell] lost grip but it just seemed to go on the other side of the road." 
When the cars crashed Grant had "very little time to react" but pulled over to the side of the road. 
"I'm damn lucky because I had a gap to pull through because you are going at 100kmh so I had zero time to react. It just happened so quickly." 
He said there appeared to be two people in each car. 
Cromwell man Adrian Hopkinson said he was returning home from Queenstown with his boss when they saw a huge amount of smoke. Ad Feedback 
"Everything was steaming and everyone was screaming. I've never seen anything like that before and I don't want to see it again." 
An Australian nurse who was on an AJ Hackett Bungy bus was one of the first to help at the scene but was struggling to get a passenger from one of the cars, he said. 
Hopkinson helped to remove the woman before the ambulance arrived and paramedics carried on giving CPR. 
An Otago Rescue Helicopter was sent from Dunedin to the scene. 
Police have reopened one lane of the road after a two-hour closure. Both lanes were expected to be open by 7pm. - Stuff
